section.title: The Graphics Controller System
section.para: A number of functions can be attributed to a graphics object; this is done by registering controllers. If you click the created polygon or line, these controlers will become active. In the example below, the object can be resized (see the square handlers that make up a box around the object), dragged and also, there is a pencil image visible on the left hand top position. If you click this, you will go to the editing mode of the object. You can change the shape of the object by dragging the existing points or add/delete points.

Clicking the pencil image puts the object in editing mode.

section.title: The Graphics Action System
section.para: The graphics project has a second way to register actions on an object. They are registered in a special controller. This controller will show up as a cog image on the top left position of the object's box, when you click the object. Clicking the cog shows a number of registered actions. Clicking Edit Shape brings the object again in an editing state.

The advantage of using the action system as supposed to the controller system for editing object, is that more than one action can be registered at the same time. You see in the example below that also actions Delete and Edit Style are active.

screenshot.screeninfo: Two polygon objects. The right one has been selected.
Clicking the cog shows an action menu.
The polygon in the editing state.

section.para: More detailed information on the graphics action registration system is explained in the documentation of the Graphics Project. The content of the cog menu depends on the properties of the graphics object. The Edit Shape action will only appear if the object has a GeometryEditable role.
